DOCNAME: CASE OF PAULSEN-MEDALEN AND SVENSSON v. SWEDEN
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Reasonable time);No violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Administrative proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , PERSON , born in DATE and unmarried , lives at FAC , a suburb of GPE . The second applicant , Mr PERSON - PERSON , born in DATE , lives at GPE , another suburb of GPE . The first applicant is the mother of CARDINAL children , P. and PERSON ; the second applicant is PERSON ’s father .

CARDINAL . The first applicant came into contact with the social authorities in DATE while expecting her first child P. Following his birth , he and his mother stayed with her parents , then with the second applicant and , as from DATE , with ORG father . After the birth of her second son PERSON in DATE the first applicant and her sons returned to her parents . In DATE she moved to ORG . Since DATE she has been living at FAC in order to be closer to her parents . During this period the social authorities provided on a regular basis the first applicant with financial support and assistance in the upbringing of her children .

CARDINAL . On DATE , in the light of an investigation by the social authorities , the Chairperson of ORG ( sociala distriktsnämnden ) in PERSON decided to take the children immediately into care on a provisional basis . The children were placed at ORG in GPE .

CARDINAL . The first applicant appealed against the decision to take the children provisionally into care . However , ORG ( länsrätten ) and ORG ( kammarrätten ) of GPE upheld the decision and ORG ( regeringsrätten ) refused the applicant leave to appeal .

CARDINAL . By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG ordered that the children P. and J. be taken into care pursuant to section CARDINAL of the Act containing Special Provisions on the Care of Young Persons DATE ( lag CARDINAL:CARDINAL med särskilda bestämmelser om vård av unga – hereinafter “ the DATE LAW ) on the ground that there were such deficiencies in the children ’s care as to endanger their health and development .
CARDINAL . The first applicant appealed against the judgment , initially in respect of both PERSON and J. She later withdrew the appeal in so far as it concerned P.
By judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG upheld the care order with respect to J.
CARDINAL . The first applicant sought to appeal against the above judgment but , on DATE , ORG refused the appeal as being lodged out of time , which decision was upheld by ORG on DATE .

CARDINAL . J. and P. were placed with foster parents on DATE and DATE in separate homes . Initially no decision regarding the first applicant ’s access to her children was taken but it appears that from DATE until DATE she was in fact able to visit her children in the foster homes once DATE for TIME . Furthermore , she could see them in her own home DATE for TIME . The second applicant normally accompanied the first applicant during her visits in the foster homes .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after the first applicant had contacted her present representative , PERSON , she requested the social authorities to confirm that no decision had been taken to restrict her right of access to her children .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Chairperson of ORG ( stadsdelsnämnden ) of GPE decided , pursuant to section CARDINAL of the DATE Act ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , to restrict the first applicant ’s access to her children to a CARDINAL hours’ visit in the foster homes DATE .

On DATE , acting in her own capacity and on behalf of her children , the first applicant appealed against the above decision to ORG . She maintained primarily that the decision had been unlawful in that the Chairperson of ORG had not been empowered to restrict access .

CARDINAL . ORG quashed the Chairperson ’s decision in a judgment of DATE . On appeal by ORG that judgment was overturned on DATE by ORG . It considered that the Chairperson had been empowered to restrict access and referred the case back to ORG for determination of the merits of the access restrictions .
The first applicant appealed against ORG judgment to ORG which , on DATE , refused leave to appeal .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the social authorities had decided to restrict the first applicant ’s right to speak to J. on the telephone to CARDINAL phone calls DATE . Furthermore , on DATE , it had decided to maintain the restrictions on the first applicant ’s access to her CARDINAL sons to a CARDINAL hours’ visit DATE in the foster homes .
CARDINAL . The above decisions were challenged before ORG which , after holding a hearing on DATE , upheld them in a judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant appealed on her own and her sons’ behalf to ORG which , following an oral hearing , rejected the appeal on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant and the children , represented by their mother , applied for leave to appeal to ORG , which was granted on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the lower courts’ judgments as regards the restrictions on access .

According to the ORG , ORG delay in giving judgment appeared to have been due to the fact that it was awaiting ORG ruling in the case of ORG and PERSON v. GPE ( judgment of DATE , Series A no . CARDINALA ) which raised similar issues in relation to restrictions on telephone communications between mother and child .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON submitted the following request to the relevant authority on behalf of the second applicant :

“ [ The second applicant ] requests access [ to J. ] DATE from DATE until DATE as from DATE . Access shall take place at [ the second applicant ’s ] home at GPE without the presence of any other persons being required . [ The second applicant ] will bring and fetch [ J. ] in the foster home .

You are requested to notify me immediately , not later than within DATE , of your acceptance of this access arrangement and to inform the foster parents thereof . If you consider that you can not decide in this matter in your capacity as a civil servant I request that you refer it to ORG , to confirm that such a referral has taken place and to inform me when I may expect a decision from ORG . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the Chief of ORG , GPE , GPE ( stadsdelsförvaltningen CARDINAL , GPE , GPE ) informed the second applicant as follows :

“ ... I must point out that LAW containing Special Provisions on ORG applies in respect of children taken into public care . As you are aware , its provisions regarding access apply only in respect of the custody holder or in respect of those who have taken care of the child . Accordingly , it is only the mother [ the first applicant ] who is covered by these provisions . Of course , a natural father is important for the child who , having regard to what is in his or her best interests , has a right of access to his or her parent . According to section CARDINAL of [ the DATE Act ] , it is the social authorities , in this case the foster home department at Tynnered District [ familjehemsverksamheten i stadsdels - förvaltningen Tynnered ] , which must decide on [ J. ’s ] personal circumstances in the foster home . [ The second applicant ] is welcome to discuss the question of access with [ the secretary responsible for foster home care ] .

... I should like to recall that it concerns a child who , because of his need of care , has been placed in a foster home by court order . It can not be considered to be in the interest of a child to be removed from his or her home DATE , especially not in a situation such as that of [ J. ] . Not even in divorce cases is it normal that access be granted with such short intervals ; such cases often do not even concern children with any special need for care being provided in their home .
In effect , what you suggest is that a non - custody holder should be granted access going beyond what the custody holder has been granted . ”
CARDINAL . The second applicant did not pursue the matter but appears to have contacted the social authorities at Frölunda to enquire about his access to J. On DATE the authorities replied :
“ A right of access to a child for a person other than the custody holder does not exist under domestic law . It is however appropriate that a child also meets his or her relatives .

ORG has decided that [ J. ’s ] access to his mother should be limited to CARDINAL visits a year , which may be increased to the extent agreed by [ J. ] . His access to other relatives should be considered in light of this . As regards [ the second applicant ’s ] request to meet [ J. ] it could be said that [ the second applicant ] participates in the regular access arranged DATE . Admittedly , [ J. ] has not appeared more than a few times during DATE but the aim is that [ J. ] attend more frequently in the future . This means that [ the second applicant ] will meet [ J. ] on the same conditions as the mother [ the first applicant ] . ”
CARDINAL . It does not appear that the second applicant has taken any further initiative to establish access to his son J.
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE PERSON had submitted a request by the maternal grandparents to ORG for the children P. and PERSON to stay with them DATE .

On DATE the ORG informed PERSON that the question regarding the PERSON access to their grandchildren was not regulated in the law . The request could , nevertheless , be examined in the context of the social authorities’ general powers to decide on the personal conditions of the children . Decisions made under these general powers were not subject to any review . The grandparents were advised to contact the social authority responsible for the foster home to discuss the possibilities of access although the access requested did not appear to be consistent with the children ’s needs .
By letter of CARDINAL DATE the grandparents insisted on having a formal decision on the subject . On DATE ORG decided that the request did not call for any further action .

CARDINAL . During the proceedings in the present case the LAW on the Care of Young Persons DATE ( LAW ) was replaced by a new LAW on the Care of Young Persons DATE ( lagen CARDINAL:CARDINAL med särskilda bestämmelser om vård av unga – “ the DATE LAW ) which entailed certain amendments and additions to LAW . LAW entered into force on DATE . According to the transitional provisions a care order issued under LAW should be regarded as a care order under the corresponding provision in LAW . The same applied with respect to decisions on access .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act provided :
“ If it is necessary in order to achieve the purposes of care measures taken under LAW , ORG may
CARDINAL . decide how the right of access to the young person shall be exercised by a parent or other person who has custody of him , or
CARDINAL . decide that the young person ’s place of residence may not be disclosed to the parent or custodian . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE Act , which replaced section CARDINAL of LAW , is worded as follows :
“ ORG is responsible for accommodating as far as possible the young person ’s needs of contact with his parents or other person who has custody of him .
If it is necessary in order to achieve the purposes of care measures taken under LAW , ORG may
CARDINAL . decide how the right of access to the young person shall be exercised by a parent or other person who has custody of him , or
CARDINAL . decide that the young person ’s place of residence may not be disclosed to the parent or custodian .
The ORG shall reconsider at least once DATE whether such decision as referred to in the second paragraph continues to be needed . ”

CARDINAL . As at present there is no authoritative ruling by ORG as to whether a parent who is not custodian or does not enjoy access rights by a court order or agreement can request a decision of ORG in respect of access .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of the DATE Act an appeal may be lodged with ORG against a decision of ORG with respect to access . ORG may review a decision by ORG in so far as its subject matter is covered by section DATE CARDINAL Act ( or section CARDINAL of the DATE Act ; see Yearbook of the Supreme Administrative Court , PERSON DATE , DATE ) .
